Title: NASM: Buffer overflow vulnerability
Synopsis:
NASM is vulnerable to a buffer overflow that allows an attacker to execute
    arbitrary code through the use of a malicious object file.

Background.Text: NASM is a 80x86 assembler that has been created for portability and modularity. NASM supports Pentium, P6, SSE MMX, and 3DNow extensions. It also supports a wide range of objects formats (ELF, a.out, COFF, ...), and has its own disassembler.

Description.Text: Jonathan Rockway discovered that NASM-0.98.38 has an unprotected vsprintf() to an array in preproc.c. This code vulnerability may lead to a buffer overflow and potential execution of arbitrary code.

Impact.Text: A remote attacker could craft a malicious object file which, when supplied in NASM, would result in the execution of arbitrary code with the rights of the user running NASM.

Workaround.Text: There is no known workaround at this time.

P.Text: All NASM users should upgrade to the latest version:
